title: 103_hr107
content:
The Act titled "Congressional Accountability Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. It applies to the application of the Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies laws related to employment terms, health and safety, and employer-employee rights to Congress, including the Social Security Act and the National Labor Relations Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 applies various labor and employment laws to Congress, including the National Labor Relations Act, Fair Labor Standards Act, Civil Rights Act, Age Discrimination Act, Occupational Safety and Health Act, Title IX, Rehabilitation Act, Privacy Act, Ethics in Government Act, Americans with Disabilities Act, and Freedom of Information Act. The Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 extends the Freedom of Information Act to Congress and applies independent counsel provisions to certain individuals within Congress. This Act covers Senators, Representatives, employees of Congress, and committee members. Employees covered under the Congressional Accountability Act of 1993 include elected officers, Legislative Counsel, Capitol Police members, and employees of Congress instrumentalities. This Act also applies to employees in the District or State Office of a Member. Employees in the District or State Office of a Member are subject to the laws set forth in section 2, treating the office as an affiliated branch of a private employer. A Member may consider political affiliation and place of residence when hiring personal staff. Section 509 of the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 is repealed, and small business exemptions apply to Members under certain laws. The small business exemption applies to Members based on the number of employees, including those working in the District of Columbia and employed by the House where the Member sits. The exemption is determined by the total number of employees necessary to qualify as a small business. SEC. 3. PROMULGATION OF IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS.

Within 180 days of this Act's enactment, the House of Representatives and the Senate must create rules to implement the Act, in line with Federal law. Failure to do so will result in being subject to Executive agency regulations.

SEC. 4. RIGHT OF APPEAL.

Individuals affected by this Act can appeal actions in Federal court, with rights and remedies as provided by relevant laws.
